The acclaimed director is behind the award-winning HBO series Succession, comedy-drama The Big Short, and the Dick Cheney biopic Vice.Parasite made Oscars history this year as the first South Korean film to be nominated for Best Picture and Best International Film. Bong&nbspwas also feted with Best Director, as well as Best Original Screenplay together with co-writer Han Jin Won.HBO’s corporate sibling TNT are also in the long process of producing a TV adaptation of Bong’s previous feature film, Snowpiercer, although Bong himself is not attached.&nbspThe best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Campaigners welcome ban but say new gambling act is needed to protect vulnerable puntersGambling customers will no longer be able to use their credit cards to place bets online in a major shake-up of industry regulations.The Gambling Commission has announced that anyone who wants to bet online from 14 April will have to use either a debit card or cash deposited into an account.The ban on credit cards will affect all gambling, with the exception of the National Lottery, following efforts by the government to tackle problem gambling and protect vulnerable customers.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Credit card gambling can lead to significant financial harm,” Neil McArthur, the commission’s chief executive, said.“The ban that we have announced today should minimise the risks of harm to consumers from gambling with money they do not have.”Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Puppeteers from Vision Mechanic rehearsing with Scotland's largest puppet, a ten-metre tall sea goddess called Storm, in the grounds of the Museum of Flight, East Lothian. I’m really proud of that, and I am really proud to work alongside the NUM since I was first elected.“Former coalfields and towns are crying out for real change. Some of these areas are part of the famous red wall that fell in the last election.I get it. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Lord Lea found guilty of harassment after telling one woman he kept photo of her on his piano and devising sexual rhyme about anotherA Labour peer has been suspended after parliamentary authorities upheld a harassment complaint relating to his behaviour towards&nbspa woman around 60 years his junior.Lord Lea, 82, sent a note to the woman, who was in her twenties, telling&nbspher that he had a framed photo of her on his piano and inviting her to share a bottle of champagne with him.The peer, who previously worked for the TUC, was also found to have harassed a&nbspsecond women after&nbspdevising&nbspa sexual rhyme about her.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe House of Lords commissioner for standards,&nbspLucy Scott-Moncrieff, ruled that his behaviour “met the criteria for harassment”&nbsprelating to&nbspage and sex in both cases and concluded that he had broken the parliamentary code of conduct. He was swiftly suspended by the Labour Peers Group, meaning he will have to sit as an independent while he completes a training programme.It emerged during the course of her investigation that Lord Lea had been the subject of 18 complaints between 2011 and 2019, including one about making a racially offensive comment and&nbsp15&nbspabout shouting at staff, aggression and making unreasonable demands.&nbspThe first complainant who spoke to Ms Scott-Moncreiff said Lord Lea had behaved inappropriately towards her during an parliamentary trip more than a decade ago by suggesting that they share&nbspa bottle of champagne in his hotel room – a suggestion denied by the peer. They instead shared the bottle of wine in a hotel lobby. title: sun says harry meghan bankrolled
story: Their plan for global domination as Instagram’s “progressive” royal power couple looks fatally flawed.First it relies on them still being bankrolled by an increasingly enraged public — as they magnanimously “work to become financially independent” despite already being worth sums most of us cannot imagine.Second, because when they finally deem their wealth vast enough to cut that umbilical cord, their livelihood will still centre around their image as senior royals . . . a role they have quit.The idea of them busily enriching themselves by flogging their part-time royalty to advertisers will disgust taxpayers — both on principle and because this ­entitled pair will never refund a penny back into Treasury coffers.The UK public will justiably demand they be cut off at the ankles, stripped of the titles on which they trade.What then for plain Meghan and Harry Wales, the narcissist formerly known as Prince Who will listen then to their vapid sermons  They might fancy themselves as the new Clintons or Obamas — but they have not earned their  or status.They were born into it, or married into it, but gave it up when it all looked too dull, too hard and not enough fun.Diehard fans will stick by them. They will doubtless make big money. But the firestorm of criticism they have ignited here will become an inferno.It is a disastrous mess and may get worse. The couple’s assumption about the public continuing to fund round-the-clock security in Canada looks ­premature — and must be reviewed.Harry is worth £million, Meghan another £million. How much richer must they be before they pay that bill WHY is the Government still so coy about celebrating the moment of Brexit Leaving the EU at pm on January  will be a huge milestone in our modern history, the end of our -year membership and the starting gun for negotiating a lucrative new era of trade.The Sun wants Big Ben to bong. We want bunting, fireworks and, yes, commemorative Royal Mail stamps.We understand the feelings of Remainers. But there were plenty of them among the million who voted last month to “get Brexit done”.The big day is less than three weeks away following its final passage through the Commons on Thursday.How typical of Labour, given one last chance to vote for the deal securing our exit, to remain childishly opposed to it.Defeated in the referendum, crushed at the election. Still they have learned nothing.[bc_video video_id account_id player_iddefault embedin-page padding_top% autoplay min_widthpx max_widthpx mute width% %captionLook inside the £m waterfront mansion Meghan Markle has ed to after the Sussexes announce their shock exit from royal duties ]GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. Harry and Meghan expect to still have a handle on royal duty but also to lead a private le.What they mean by living financially independent, I don’t know. They aren’t financially independent now — they get £.- million from the Prince Of Wales and about five per cent from the Sovereign Grant.Harry is reasonably wealthy but not necessarily in cash flow. The sums he inherited from his mother and great grandmother have been invested.Meghan has some means but to live the sort of lestyle they are used to takes a lot of money.It is conceivable Charles could cut the money he gives to Harry —he gives him any at all. Being a dad, he probably will.But there are tax implications — particularlythere are handouts.Security has also to be considered. Harry is a prince of the United Kingdom, his grandmother head of state and father heir.The atmosphere at the meeting will be, up to a point, heated. But people won’t lose their tempers.The Queen is pragmatic. She understands problems people have but Harry will be fully aware of her displeasure. To go off half-cocked as he and Meghan did is unacceptable.The question is how dare they do that. She signed up for this. So what’s changed their minds I’d love to be a fly on the wall of the events in that meeting . . . provided no one has a fly swat!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. She has a son mired in a squalid sex scandal. And she is  years old. Who the hell do Harry and Meghan think they are This feels like an abdication with a taxpayer-funded safety net. The couple plan to “step back as senior members of the Royal Family” but show no inclination to give up the privileges and pay days that come with the job.They say they want to “work to become financially independent”. But between them they are currently worth around £million. Why not pay their own way NOW Are they really suggesting that they turn their backs on this nation while asking it to foot their bills  It looks like it. The British taxpayer will continue to stump up for their phenomenal security bills. Harry’s daddy will cough up for much .So you can’t help wondering how intelligent they really are, this TV soap actress and a man who left Eton with two A-levels— a school where my dog could get four A-levels.Do Harry and Meghan really think they have had a raw deal  Are they that stupid  There is no republican movement in this country.The Queen has reigned far too well for far too long —  years on the throne next month — for anti-monarchy sentiment to develop.The Queen has spent her entire le placing public duty above private happiness.She has been the stable, stoic centre of this nation for so long that she has single-handedly made losing our monarchy unthinkable.Yet when a spokesman for anti-monarchy pressure group Republic demanded Harry and Meghan make a clean break, I found myself nodding in agreement with every withering word.“Theyhave said that they will dip in and out of royal duties as it suits them but won’t stop taking money until they find other sources of income,” said Republic’s Graham Smith.“To suggest they’re not already financially independent is incredibly crass and belies a sense of entitlement and lack of self-awareness common among royals.”This republican is right. If Harry and Meghan want a new le hanging out with the Clooneys and striking deals with Apple, they should fund it themselves.As they say in North America, do it on your own dime. Give up the HRH titles. Stop leeching off your royal status.They will be a footnote in the story of our Royal Family, Meghan the Wallis Simpson of the st Century, Harry another Duke of Windsor who believed exile with his American orcee would make him happy.The Royal Family is not all about them.The Queen will be an impossible act to follow. But the photograph of Queen Elizabeth smiling proudly with the next three generations of future kings — Princes Charles, William and George — suggests our Royal Family will last for at least  years after Netflix has cancelled The Crown, evenone day Meghan gets to play herself.The succession is assured. Decent men will wear the crown. And Kate is great. But let history record that no royal couple was ever as adored as Harry and Meghan.It is astonishing — and unbelievably sad, perhaps even tragic — that millions of us will be happy to see the back of them.Astrological patterns repeat in families through generations, just as it is doing with Meghan and Harry.Edward VIII, who wed American orcee Wallis Simpson, put love before duty, and planted a karmic seed that is at the root of what is unfolding now. It can be likened to a virus that has been lurking in the Royal household and is now being re-activated by Harry and Meghan.So what comes next  Uranus, the planet of shock-waves, moves to confront the Sun in Aquarius on January  and forms a clash with the New Moon on the th.There is likely to be a stinging backlash as all the remaining senior family members have their roles shaken up.Meghan will create a power couple that flourishes by spring with a number of initiatives. By December , another baby announcement is likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. I predict he will live to regret it. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen must be firm harry meghan
story: So we hope that Meghan and Harry can come to a suitable arrangement with the rest of the royals.But what’s clear is the couple must not receive a penny from the state.British taxpayers fund the Royal Family to strengthen our nation’s soft power, and to support vital charities.If Meghan and Harry can’t be bothered with the legwork, then it goes without saying they must give up the whopping perks which come with it.As for security, claims that to stay safe the pair need cash from daddy just won’t wash. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are rich beyond the wildest dreams of almost everyone in the UK.They are more than capable of paying for a few bodyguards. Andthey find themselves struggling, they could always cut down on the private jets.The Queen, Charles and Wills must be firm: the Sussexes have made their bed. Now they’ve got to lie in it.A CIVILISED nation treats its veterans with respect.Which is why we were delighted when Boris Johnson won the election on a manesto promising to end witch hunt prosecutions against ageing former soldiers who served in Northern Ireland.But to get Stormont up and running, the Prime Minister has brokered a deal with Sinn Fein which risks opening up new probes into thousands of Troubles veterans. This would be morally indefensible and politically mad.Yes, a working government in Northern Ireland would be a good thing. But the safety and wellbeing of our elderly veterans is too big a price tag.And given Boris won the election by being a proud patriot, it makes political sense for him to stand by the armed forces through thick and thin.If the PM is to hold the hard-earned trust of new Conservative voters, he must never give way to those who would put our old soldiers in the dock.IT would be fair to assume that anyone injecting plastic into someone’s face should have some qualications to do so.But a strange loophole in the law means that though Botox is classied as a medicine in Britain, dermal fillers aren’t covered by any regulation.A staggering  per cent of facial fillers are performed by people with no medical training, often in unsanitary conditions — with devastating results.Which is why The Sun’s Fabulous brand is launching the Had Our Fill campaign, urging for a crackdown on unregulated cosmetic fillers, and raising awareness to help women make safer, more informed choices.We’ve had our fill of dodgy fillers. title: chloe ayling kidnap reduced sentence
story: Lukasz Herba, , was convicted last year for bundling terried Chloe into a holdall and driving her to an isolated farmhouse with his brother Michal.The Brit based pair claim they abducted the model as part of a publicity stunt and both are serving long term jail sentences in Italy where they snatched her.But now an Appeal Court has ruled Lukasz should have almost five years taken off his sentence because he acted compassionately during the kidnap in Milan in July .In its judgement the court noted he acted out of love adding that he had not abandoned her in an isolated area when he released her but driven her to the British consulate in Milan.The unusual mitigating circumstances mean that he will now serve  years and one month instead of the  years and nine months he was originally given.Lukasz was sentenced in  after former Big Brother star Chloe, , described how she had been kidnapped in Milan when she turned up for a bogus photoshoot.Mum of one Chloe, from Coulsdon, south west London, has insisted it was not a publicity stunt despite eyebrows being raised by sceptics.The brothers claimed she was in on the plot which would have seen her auctioned as a sex slave to a shadowy internet group called Black Death unless a £, ransom was paid.Last month she confessed to a threesome with Dan Osborne and Natalia Nunn and she has also dated former Premier League footballer Jermaine Pennant.In December Polish born Michal, , was given  years for his part in the kidnap after being extradited from Oldbury, West Midlands, where he loved with his brother.Chloe appeared at his trial last summer via video link and broke down in tears as he relieved her traumatic ordeal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle racism press bigotry
story: By “they” I mean the liberal-Left commentariat, the people who hate Brexit, hate ordinary people and have, for some reason, grown to love our departing royals, Prince Harry and Meghan.This past  hours they have closed ranks around the couple, who have announced they plan to keep their royal titlesbut leave behind their royal duties — like some woke version of the Queen’s Guard.They have chastised anyone outraged by the staggering entitlement shown by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who have essentially said they want the status but none of the responsibilities of monarchy.They insist the poor couple have been driven out by racism.British author Afua Hirsch, writing in the New York Times, decries the “racist treatment of Meghan” in the Press.She says it is hardly a surprise Meghan has walked away from a nation with a Prime Minister “whose track record includes overtly racist statements” and a “Brexit project linked to native nationalism”.Boris Johnson has no such track record and the only people linking Brexit to native nationalism are elitist, upper-crust Remainers like Hirsch.But no matter. Why let reality spoil the narrative These claims made about the “racist” treatment of Meghan at the hands of the British Press are incredibly thin.The same non-examples are recycled over and over again. You have probably seen them quoteda thousand times.There is that Daily Mail piece from , when Harry and Meghan were first dating, that said she was “ straight outta Compton”.At the time, Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland lived in nearby Crenshaw, LA.Hirsch says this was an attempt to link Meghan with “racialised forms of crime”, meaning gangs.That is one hell of a reach. The piece was clearly just playing on the dference in Harry and Meghan’s social backgrounds.If Harry had been dating a white, working-class woman from Manchester’s Moss Side, I dare say the Mail would have done something similarly silly.Another favourite is that weird throwaway line Boris Johnson’s sister Rachel wrote, in a laudatory piece on Meghan, about the mixed-race American actress bringing some “rich and exotic DNA” to the pale Windsor bloodline. That is more cringey than racist.Several pieces have cited a single phrase in a Sarah Vine column for the Mail — she said she had a “niggling worry” about the royal couple’s engagement photo — as a bigoted dog whistle. That is, quite frankly, mental.Such is the lack of actual examples of the Press being racist about Meghan.The only leg this argument has left to stand on is that the sheer volume of criticism sent Meghan’s way was disproportionate.Racism is the only explanation for it. It’s an argument based purely on unveriable speculation and imputing motives. It is also b*****ks.When the couple first got together, the coverage was gushing across the board.It was only when Meghan and Harry started on their ious virtue-signalling cru-sades — such as jetting around to lecture on climate change — that people’s backs went up.That the couple had already been beefing with the Press probably didn’t help either.In , way before Meghan became a figure in our culture wars, Harry issued a remarkable statement rebuking journalists for the “racial undertones” of their pieces.That these privileged royals, kept in the lap of luxury at taxpayers’ expense, began to develop a deep-seated victim complex only heightened the resentment towards them.Last year, Meghan told ITV public le was a “struggle” and she was shocked that “not many people have askedI’m OK”. Poor princess.This picture of privilege is who the liberal Left has spent the best part of three years defending.Even supposed republicans have — after a bit of anti-royal throat-clearing — defended Harry and Meghan to the hilt and helped con- struct this absurd narrative that they are the victims of establishment racism.This says far more about the prejudices of liberal-Left commentators than it does about the tabloid Press. They routinely suggest Meghan’s supposed mistreatment in Brexit Britain is no coincidence.They think Britain is a foul place full of foul people, brainwashed by foul news- papers to hate the wonderful Duchess of Sussex and the brilliant European Union.What the liberal elite’s Meghanmania shows us is that, for all their posturing against right-wingers, monarchy and the old aristocracy, they are title: american airlines employee sent creepy texts to passenger saying she looks good in her top and offering her free seats
story: The man, named only as Ahmad, began sending the texts to Ashley Barno as she was waiting to board a flight to Chicago from San Diego International Airport in April.“Hey, Ashley! How are you ” the first message read.Barno replied: “I’m good, thank you! Sorry. I’m not sure who this is.”A second text didnt reveal the senders identity, but told Barno: “BTW I must tell you that you are gorgeous.Speaking later to NBC, Barno said: “The whole time I kept asking him, ‘Who are you How do you know who I am  How’d you get my info A third text telling Barno she was looking gorgeous in that gray top today prompted her to look around her at the boarding gate, but she couldnt see anyone she recognised.The sender then identied himself as a man named Ahmad, who said he worked for American Airlines.After Barno had boarded her flight, she received another message reading: “I am on board now. Are you going to Chicago too  ”She said the messages had begun to make her extremely uncomfortable.“Just knowing that he knew what I looked like, and that we were in an enclosed plane and that there’s no way out, like really, really scared me, she said.Barno tried to get Ahmad to stop sending the messages, writing: Not ok! Not cool. Leave me alone.Ahmad responded: “Ok it’s up to you, but friendship with me will be very beneficial for you.“I can always give you good seats, access to the lounges, and free drinks.”Barno then spoke to a member of the planes crew, who confirmed Ahmad worked for the airline and that he had behaved in a similar way in the past.She said the crew member was furious about what Ahmad had done and amazingly helpful.Officials from the airline were then waiting to escort Ahmad from the plane after it arrived in Chicago.Ashley, who says the experience left her in tears, later learned Ahmad had gotten her number and home address by looking at a tag on her suitcase.She later received a phone call from American Airlines to discuss what had happened, but was later unable to find out whether it had disciplined or dismissed Ahmad or reviewed its privacy assurances.She is now taking legal action against the carrier for negligent hiring and sexual harassment.A statement given to NBC by the airline said: “American Airlines takes the privacy and safety of our customers very seriously.While we can’t discuss details about this inidual case, we investigated the allegations and took appropriate action.”GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. view’, but soon changed her mind once she realised I was black.“I wasn’t expecting her to even ask me about my background as I didn’t think it was relevant and she even had the nerve to say it wasn’t racist.Mr Mboob added how the ordeal has left him feeling self-conscious when cooking African food in case other people have the same perception.“She even tried to play it down by saying how she has Nigerian friends and that all their houses smell like what they cook,” he concluded.“I’ve just moved in with new housemates and I’ve developed serious anxiety about cooking around them in case they hate the smell too.”Ms Vimbsone declined to comment when approached by The Sun Online.Under the Race Relations Act it is unlawful for a landlord to discriminate against a tenant on racial grounds.The Act defines racial grounds as including race, colour, nationality or ethnic or national origins.According to the Race Relations Act, there are four main types of racial discrimination: direct, indirect, victimisation and harassment.Direct racial discrimination takes place when you are able to show that you have been treated less favorably on racial grounds than others in a comparable situation.It occurs when:Refusing to rent or let a property based on race is unlawful as it breaches section  of the Equality Act .In , Fergus Wilson – Britain’s biggest buy-to-let landlord – banned ”coloured” people - because he said they make his properties smell of curry.Mr Wilson issued the directive in an email to lettings agents Evolution, who handled some of his hundreds of rental properties.The email, which was leaked to The Sun, listed his requirements for potential tenants.One said: “No coloured people because of the curry smell at the end of the tenancy.”Mr Wilson, , who was once reported to own up to , properties in Kent, said: “To be honest, we’re getting overloaded with coloured people.“It is a problem with certain types of coloured people - those who consume curry - it sticks to the carpet.”

title: mum living in moulded infested flat hertfordshire
story: Lisa Dyer, , shares the property in Potters Bar, Hertfordshire, with daughters, Angel, nine, Skylar, two, and -month-old Zara.Ms Dyer, who has lived in the two-bedroom housing association flat for seven years, said shes at “breaking point” – as walls plagued with mould cover the entirety of her family home.“Since September last year, things have just been getting worse and I can’t live in this place anymore,” she told the Hertfordshire Mercury.“I’ve had numerous people come out to clear the mould and a man even came over to clear it and he literally told me ‘you can’t live in a place like this, you need to get your children out of here’.Things have even reached the stage where the young mum has contemplated taking her own le.She continued: “There’s been so many times when I’ve wanted to end my le, but I wouldn’t do that to my kids – I’m a very strong person and it takes a lot to break me.“I don’t know what  to do, I’m a single mother with three kids and the whole place, it’s completely and utterly awful.”Shockingly, Ms Dyer claims her health, as well as her children’s, has declined due to the “mould infestation” situation – and has even been hospitalised because of it.  She said: “A few years ago, I was diagnosed with asthma because of the mould and damp – now my daughter has also been diagnosed with it.“Just this morning, she woke up and said she can’t breathe, I don’t know what to do – my other little girl also isn’t sleeping anymore.“I’ve had three asthma attacks recently and I was in hospital just three or four weeks ago.”A spokesperson from  housing association Catalyst responded in a statement, saying: “Providing our customers with a safe and comfortable home is our priority.“We are sorry for the distress caused to Ms Dyer, and we’re working to fix the issues within her home as quickly as possible.”

He said: The case for a radical Labour government has never been stronger”. And he called for the party to take on the narrative that Boris Johnson can aposget Brexit doneapos by the end of January.  REBECCA LONG-BAILEY,  -   Salford  Eccles  PROFILE: John McDonnell’s and other Corbyn alliesapos preferred successor for Jeremy Corbyn, the shadow chancellor has been grooming her for the top job. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDelighted Debbie and Ste Hodge are finally quids in after buying a house for a pound and turning it into a £, asset. They put “blood, sweat and tears” into the two-bed dump, bought under a council regeneration scheme. Debbie and Ste were shaken when they first stepped through the door – armed with a £, schedule of works from Liverpool City Council to bring it up to scratch. The th century terraced house had been hit by fire and had crumbling walls, broken bricks and burnt joists. But the couple worked -, did most of the renovations themselves and in  months transformed it into a cosy home for just £,. After enjoying their first Christmas in the double-fronted home in the city’s Wavertree district, the pair have been buoyed by a valuation of £,. Debbie, , says: “We never want to move because we have put so much of ourselves into this house. People thought we were nuts. “We’ve crawled on the floors, we built the floors… it’s a gamble we took and we love it. Our blood and guts have gone into it. If they’d give us next door, we’d do it again!” Recalling the first time she saw the property, Debbie says: “It was just a shell. All the joists were burnt. It was terrible. “Honestly, it was just stacks and stacks of bricks. There was nothing. My family were saying to me, ‘You’re mad’.”  Every floor had to be replaced, chimneys were removed, the sinking kitchen was underpinned, all fittings were ripped out and the windows were upgraded. Debbie and Ste, , used their savings and took a small loan to complete the work – and it was hard graft. We were there until midnight with torches. We went seven days a week, we didn’t miss a day,” Debbie says. She scoured local ads for bargains and bagged a £, kitchen for a tenth of the price and a £, bathroom suite for £,. They also picked up a slightly damaged £, front door for £.  And, slowly but surely, the place came together. Now it is a shining example of how Liverpool is breathing new le into former slums. A similar scheme has since been launched in Stoke-on-Trent. Last year, a Channel  documentary about the renovations in Liverpool featured Debbie and Ste. The Hodges used to rent in Anfield and had struggled to get a mortgage. Debbie suffered a serious long-term illness and Ste’s wages as a carpet cleaner were not enough to secure a home loan. Debbie says: “The council scheme was the best thing to happen to us. It brings communities together. When we moved in, there were only about three houses in the road occupied. But it’s moving on now, it’s coming to be more of a community and about half the street is filled.  “We’ve met all the neighbours and introduced ourselves. title: darren lewis harry  meghan
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are right to put themselves firstThey are young people who want to go their own way, says Mirror Columnist Darren Lewis, millions of families have themShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf they want out, howled the critics, they should give up the taxpayer cash and their positions in the Royal Family. Fair enough, said Harry and Meghan, we will. Cue the eruption. The critics want to have their cake and eat it. As in any dysal situation, they dismiss anything from the Sussexes unless it falls into line with whatever they want. Harry – forced to walk through London behind his mother’s coffin as a -year-old – can’t open up on his mental health issues without being attacked as weak. Meghan can’t breathe without being vilied for showing a lack of consideration to the Queen, the Crown, the flag and the Empire. The Sussexes are not allowed to set their own boundaries. Not when “duty” demands they are there to be pushed around.Of course, race has played a part in it. That much is obvious to large sections of black and white Britain. Yes, Camilla, Diana and Sarah Ferguson were also treated badly, but not like this. Not with the sustained vitriol that Meghan has had to endure. From her son being mocked up as a chimp to criticising her for editing Vogue – even though Prince Harry edited Radio ’s Today programme and Kate edited the Huffington Post website. Social media critics claimed bi-racial Meghan was not pure enough to marry into the Firm. The inference has always been that she doesn’t belong. She has been derided as a a, intent on wrecking the Royal Family. The so-called “constitutional crisis” is Harry and Meghan fighting back.  They are young people who want to go their own way. Millions of families have them. Kids who decide they want no part of the way things have been done in the past, children of rock stars who aren’t interested in music, footballers’ kids who don’t like sport. Frankly, the Sussexes are right to put themselves and their own wellbeing first. Of course, Home Secretary Priti Patel can’t see the problem. She serves under a Prime Minister whose overt racism is well documented. This debate, however, could yet become a turning point for our media. Most of the royal commentators stamping their feet over this are white. Most of the newsrooms covering this are largely white. The real time backlash is from black Britons with a digital  who are determined to have their say.  Angry, polarised race-baiting for social media hits is not the answer. The solution is a better ethnic mix in our media to give us an understanding of how to address this issue. Royal Author Penny Junor was left stumped on CBS This Morning when she vehemently insisted race was not a factor in Meghan’s treatment. “Did you check in with any black Britons before you made that determination ” asked the presenter. Junor was left stuttering. It appeared she hadn’t. All Meghan has done is back her husband as he chooses to move out of his grandmother’s house and fend for himself.

Her Majesty had appealed for calm in the face of days of tension from her family and household staff that had threatened to boil over. Those battling against the winds of change as Harry and we Meghan plotted their move away, were beckoned to the table to carve a way forward. With the world’s eyes on a tiny corner of Norfolk, the -year-old monarch presided over one of the most extraordinary days of her seven decade reign. Chairing the meeting, across a large polished table with room for eight chairs, the Queen and her family set out their vision of how a new version of monarchy would emerge. Over the next two hours they thrashed out the framework of a deal to stop the Duke and Duchess of Sussex from permanently turning their backs on the family. But the brutal reality remained, that little more than  months after marrying in a wedding that captured the hearts of the nation, Harry and Meghan had effectively resigned from The Firm citing feelings of relentless pressure and an unsupportive network  The couple, who have patented more than  items from intellectual property to bandanas, plan a takeover on the global stage where they can earn millions with Meghan’s star power and Hollywood connections lining up to help. But with Harry wavering under renewed requests for calm from his beloved grandmother, the hope is the family will still be able to persuade the couple to change tack and plan a soft Megxit to safeguard their future and the monarchy for a generation. Sources close to the negotiations have revealed the family set six main points to be agreed on before real change could take affect.  The six key points Titles The Queen referred to the couple by their first names and not by their titles in her statement. Does this mean they will lose their titles  Finances The couple have been asked to suggest a plan to fulfil their wish to be “financially independent”. Deals to be approved by The Palace. Protection The Queen and other royals have vowed to find a “workable approach” to security issues. Canada has reportedly said it would pay.  Advisers The pair took advice from PR gurus in the US, Sir Elton John and Oprah Winfrey. Senior royals want to know exactly who works for them. Media plan Senior royals will demand to knowHarry and Meghan are planning to do a ‘tell-all’ interview – and who would host it. Where they live Any new home would have to be assessed by the UK security services and Buckingham Palace due to security concerns. What happens next  Crucially with the Queen’s blessing, Harry and Meghan will now split their time between the UK and Canada as “a period of transition” takes place, nullying the need for the immense haste which the Sussexes had been so keen to implement. Central to discussions was the way in which the couple will move towards becoming “financially independent” They revealed they would stop claiming public funds, believed to be in excess of a £million a year, but it is thought they would still claim expenses for travel and office costs Despite being worth more than £million in their own right, the couple are still yet to announce whether they will give up the £. million a year subsidy from Prince Charles from his private income. Their security bill has still to be managed, set between £, and £million, considerably moreiding their time between countries.  They were buoyed today by reports Canadian prime minister has agreed to foot the bill when the duke and duchess are residents in his country. Justin Trudeau had previously tweeted “‘You’re among friends, and always welcome here’” when news broke of the Sussexes escape to Vancouver for their extended break over Christmas and new year. The Queen’s advisors have made clear the Sussexesapos responsibilities moving forward when signing corporate deals and Harry has agreed he would never purposely seek to bring controversy to his family.  He told how neither he nor his we have plans to do a tell all interview after close associates of the couple said that any proposition would not be pretty for the monarchy. Key to any discussions moving forward will be the Queen’s private secretary Sir Edward Young, Prince Charles’s canny private secretary Clive Alderton and William’s top aide and former civil servant Simon Case. Prince Harry’s private secretary, ex-diplomat Fiona Mcilwham, is expected to complete the group. The Sussexesapos living arrangements are to be mapped out by advisors once Harry and Meghan come up with a range of options.  It is expected they will keep their Frogmore Cottage home that was refurbished with £. million of taxpayers cash just last year. After the meeting the three male principals staged a synchronised exit from the estate in separate cars, with Charles later flying from RAF Marham around  miles away to his Scottish retreat Birkhall where he always has a New Year break. As the sun set on the grounds outside the room where discussions had taken place and the satellite vans of the worlds media trundled off, the Queen was left to consider what the future would look for her family and the country she has serves with distinction after this most historic day.

story: NewsNeglected boy, , found living in rubbish tip home with no toys fit to play withWARNING - DISTRESSING CONTENT: The home was found littered with heroin needles, rotting food and infestations of flies when social services and the police arrived to find the boy in "absolute squalor"ShareBySuzy Gibson:,  JAN NewsThe boy was suffering from worms and told police his only toy in the house was the toaster " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA neglected seven-year-old boy was found living in a home that resembled a rubbish tip, alongside his drug addict parents. The home was found littered with heroin needles, rotting food and infestations of flies when social services and the police arrived. Leicester Crown Court heard the youngster had vanished off the local authorityaposs radar after moving schools - despite not showing up to school for six months, reports Leicestershire Live. Alexander Wolfson, prosecuting, said there was a multi-agency meeting in December , before the police attended an address in Leicester and found it to be in absolute squalor. He said: The conditions were disgusting, with rotting food and piles of rubbish everywhere. The bedrooms, lounge and bathroom were filthy. The kitchen was rancid with a couple of tins of food left open and evidence of mouse droppings. The stove was inaccessible, there was mouldy food in the fridge and it was dficult to move around. Unfortunately drugs paraphernalia was lying about items associated with taking heroin, with uncapped needles. Cigarette ash was evident and flies. Bags of rubbish were on the upstairs landing. When a drawer in the boyaposs bedroom cupboard was opened a cloud of flies flew into the air, said the prosecutor. He added: There were faeces marks across a wall. The toilet was filthy with no evidence of a toothbrush or toothpaste in the bathroom. The child didnapost appear to have a change of clothes and didnapost have pyjamas. He was not wearing underwear or socks. He did not appear to have toys fit to play with. The boy told officers he had eaten some cookies during the day, but did not appear to have had anything . The foster parents he was placed with reported that he did not want to wash, brush his teeth or have his hair washed and was terried of flies. He was always hungry and had dficulty understanding the dference between day and night. He had not been registered with a GP and needed medication for worms.  The child was placed in school and assessed as being two years behind. However, he did not appear to be malnourished or to have any other medical issues. Mr Wolfsen said the child said he had played on an XBox a lot when living with his parents. He ate bread and butter with ketchup and played with the toaster in his fatheraposs bedroom - and went to bed when he liked. When interviewed, the father said multiple bereavements had left him unable to cope, and he went into a drug-induced downward spiral. The mother accepted the house was in a poor condition saying she only lived there because she had nowhere . Both parents, who are not being named because of a court order protecting the boyaposs identity, pleaded guilty to an offence of child cruelty by neglect. Mr Wolfsen said: Heaposs been doing well in short-term foster care and will be placed into long-term foster care. He has a bright future ahead of him. Heaposs desperate to see his mum and dad and is described as being fiercely loyal to them - and asks about them. They are having supervised contact with him. The distressed mother wept in the dock during the hearing.  Judge Ebraham Mooncey said: This is a dficult sentencing exercise. When it involves an innocent child who has clearly suffered, anyoneaposs instincts would be to mete the harshest penalties on those responsible. One has to look at the facts and the circumstances. He told the parents: The prosecutor tells me youaposve had contact with your son and heaposs expressed a desire to continue contact with you and that he loves you both. Heaposs fiercely loyal to both of you. He obviously now has a bright future and the hardship heaposs suffered is potentially something that can be put behind him. Iaposm dealing with two people who werenapost, by any measure, capable of looking after a child. Iaposve been given details about what led to this awful situation arising. Both of you, historically, have drug problems and thataposs affected the way you live your lives. The court heard that one of the childaposs grandparents had been actively involved in helping to properly care for the boy at a dferent address, but when she died he ended up living where with his parents.  Other deaths in the family led to his father relapsing into former class A drug addiction. The judge said: The photographs of the house speak for themselves. Some of the rooms look like rubbish tips. Heroin needles were around, there was rotten food and flies. A police officer says, in his statement, he retched and almost threw up when he went into the house. Itaposs very fortunate the child has made a full recovery. This wasnapost evil out-and-out cruelty. The parents are themselves incapable and inadequate. There are positive measures now in their lives, in the sense of dealing with their addictions. Philip Gibbs, mitigating for the father, who is in his s, said: The defendant loves his son. Itaposs clear from the photographs he failed in his duty to care for his son.  He says prior to moving there the boy was perfectly looked after. The father, who had been clean of drugs for several years before relapsing, disagreed with some of the prosecution claims, saying the boy was given baths but had an aversion to bathing. He was taken out, he was also fed - as there was evidence of cereal boxes and take-aways. The boy had been taught how to use a kne and fork, it was claimed. He and the childaposs mother accept they struggled to maintain the house, said Mr Gibbs. The father claimed he did not seek help for fear of having his son taken away. Mr Gibbs said: He apologises to his son over and above all . They have supervised contact and the bond remains. The child loves his dad and his mum - itaposs a human tragedy. Itaposs alarming a child can disappear out of the school system for thatof time. The boy went into foster case without any real medical concerns and has thrived.

story: NewsTributes to non-smoking mum-of-three, , killed by lung cancer on Christmas DaySam Platts has vowed to tackle the belief that lung cancer only affects smokers following the death of his -year-old we Debbie on the morning of December ShareCommentsByNick DawsonLorraine King:,  JAN NewsDebbie Platts died of cancer on Christmas Day " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe widower of a non-smoking mum has vowed to tackle the belief that lung cancer only affects smokers following her death on Christmas Day.Debbie Platts died at home in Sapcote at the age of  on Christmas morning, after a two year battle with lung cancer. The selfless former nurse, and mum of three daughters, shared her story through a popular blog and Facebook Page as she wanted to comfort and support others living with the illness. Sam said she remained positive right until the end despite becoming almost unable to walk, Leicestershire Live reports.“It’s been a rough couple of years but the last few months have been really rough. Her illness took over quite a lot towards the end”, he said. The -year-old said he is determined to keep raising awareness of lung cancer, as people misconceive that it’s a smoker’s illness, whereas Debbie never smoked. Paying tribute to same, who he married in summer , he said: “She was beautul, she was amazing, she was the nicest, most caring woman I met. She was brilliant, always smiling, even at the end.” Debbie first became ill in February  when she woke up one morning with excruciating back pain and a chest infection. As her pain persisted, she decided to get checked out and a CT scan and biopsy revealed she had a mass on her left lung.  Doctors told Debbie and Sam the devastating news that she had terminal cancer which could only be managed by treatment. Debbie was determined to carry on with le as normal and created a Facebook page, Nurse with the big “C”urse, where she regularly posted photos and updates about her treatment and future plans. She said last year: “I didn’t want sympathy or pity, I just wanted my story to be heard, because when you are given a diagnosis like this, you can have all your close family and friends with you but still feel so isolated, scared and alone.” She spoke of the challenge of living with cancer, saying: “It’s one of the last things I think of at night and within minutes of being awake, it’s there at the forefront of my mind. “I try to distract myself thinking of all the wonderful things I am yet to experience and places I need to visit. It helps me to cope. “I need those goals to aim towards so that on the bad days, it’s my loved ones, goals and memories that get me through.” After Debbie and Sam got married they spent time in Ibiza and Rhodes, despite her illness. Her family announced her death with a post on the Facebook page.  It urged people to “hold on to everyone you love a little tighter and a little longer tonight and never take the good times for granted because le can be so cruel and snatch those precious moments away.”Sam said: “We still did Christmas dinner and everyone came round. In fact, more people came round than we expected.“We had about  to  people. It’s what she would have wanted.” Her funeral at South Leicestershire crematorium was attended by around  people where Chanel read out a poem that was written especially for the occasion.  Sam and around  family friends are taking part in a charity bike ride from Leicester to Skegness in aid of Loros Hospice, who provided care for Debbie in her final weeks. They also plan to keep the blog and Facebook page going. Asked what advice he would give to a family whose loved one had just been given a terminal cancer diagnosis, Sam said: “Everyone takes things dferently, it’s such a hard thing to deal with. “You have to try and be as positive as possible. Look into all the options you have got.

title: woman who seven miscarriages finally
story: NewsWoman who had seven miscarriages finally to become a mum - thanks to her best palSophie Smith, , Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, was unable to have children of her own after two ectopic pregnancies required both of her fallopian tubes to be removedShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSophie Smith, , with her partner Jack " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman who suffered seven heartbreaking miscarriages is finally about to become a mum - thanks to her best friend of  years. Sophie Smith, , and her husband Jack, , had given up hope of ever becoming parents to their own children after spending six years and £, on IVF desperately trying to conceive. The couple, from Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, went through five devastating miscarriages and two ectopic pregnancies that required both of her fallopian tubes to be removed - leaving Sophie unable to have children of her own. But their despair turned to joy when Sophieaposs best friend, Emiliana Hall, stepped in and offered to carry a baby for the couple. The mum-of-two was pregnant with her son Theo, now two, at the time but was determined to give her friends ‘the greatest gt of le’.  And now, the best pals - who stuck up a friendship on their first day in secondary school - are delighted to be shopping for baby-grows together as Emiliana is six-months pregnant with Sophie and Jackaposs baby. Sophie, a fashion buyer, said: I believe it was fate that I met Em at -years-old during our first year of secondary school. “If someone had told me  years ago, that one of my best friends would go on to carry my genetic baby I would have laughed. “But all that time has been building up this moment, one I now believe was always meant to be. “We have always had a strong friendship, even after she once ordered four taxis to turn up to my house at am on a school night as a joke. “She has saved us from our immense pain and given us back our hope by offering to be our surrogate.  In , Sophie fell pregnant for the first time - two weeks ahead of Emiliana – sadly an early scan at seven weeks for Sophie revealed an ectopic pregnancy. She said: “It was pretty much what you always dream about - sharing pregnancy and motherhood at the same time as my best friend. But on the day, Em told me she was pregnant too I was experiencing stomach pains. “I was rushed to AE after a scan revealed an ectopic pregnancy - this resulted in tube removal. “It was incredibly scary and emotionally heart-breaking. “It was dficult for both of us to be on very dferent paths to parenthood, but we it never affected our friendship. It had been six years of emotional turmoil for the fashion buyer who never got to hear a heartbeat as she miscarried at six to seven weeks each time. Emiliana would always offer a shoulder to cry on and would be one of the first to find out about Sophie’s heartache. She said: “Em would always come around, even when I didn’t want to talk but she would be there to support us. “It never got any easier and I began to feel like I constantly had a lump permanently in my throat.  “It became so painful to hear someone  get pregnant and to hear that they had seen a heartbeat on a scan. “The envy and jealousy were immense and then the guilt about feeling this way would set in and the vicious circle continued. “But I would still be there as much as I could for friends pregnancies, baby showers and when babies arrived as it was always my priority to not let my infertility affect friendships. “I guessed Em was pregnant with Theo, I had been through five miscarriages, so I was familiar with the signs of somebody not wanting to tell me. “She was pretty quiet and said we need to meet up, so I knew straight away – it is bittersweet because I was happy for her but sad for me. “I became pretty depressed my mental health definitely took a nosee - I felt like I was just surviving le watching everyone  move on and have babies of their own. “ During Emiliana’s second pregnancy, the grieving couple took a career break and spent two months travelling around Australia – on their , Sophie suffered another ectopic pregnancy. She describes it as the ‘nail in the coffin’ as her second fallopian tube was removed.  Although they had never thought about surrogacy before, Emiliana offered whilst pregnant as she wanted to put an end to their pain. Emiliana, who is a hypnobirthing teacher, said: “I thought about being a surrogate for two months before proposing the idea to Sophie as it isn’t the type of thing you can say and go back on. “I wanted to make sure I was serious and that my partner James was happy for me to go ahead with it. “I think him seeing Jack in so much emotional pain over the years has made it an easy decision for him too. “We often say, ‘nine months of our lives for their whole le to change’. “I wrote a letter to Sophie and Jack, so they had it in writing and to show I really meant it.” Four-year-old Mollie and Theo, two, were read a children’s book on surrogacy so they can understand. Sophie adds: “I bought them a book so they can understand as best as they can, Theo is a little too young but Mollie knows the baby isnapost mine.
